questions.text: Which muscle is implicated in ptosis in Horner syndrome?
questions.solution:
Horner syndrome results from a disruption in the sympathetic pathway to the eye, leading to a characteristic triad:

  • Mild ptosis (drooping of the upper eyelid)
  • Miosis (pupillary constriction)
  • Anhidrosis (loss of sweating on the affected side)

The ptosis seen in Horner syndrome is due to dysfunction of the Müller muscle, also known as the superior tarsal muscle, which is a sympathetically innervated muscle responsible for maintaining 2-3 mm of eyelid elevation.

Levator aponeurosis (Option B): The levator palpebrae superioris muscle is responsible for major eyelid elevation and is innervated by the oculomotor nerve (CN III).

Damage to the oculomotor nerve, not the sympathetic pathway, leads to severe ptosis, unlike the mild ptosis in Horner syndrome.

Horner muscle (Option C): There is no specific muscle called "Horner muscle" in human anatomy.

Orbicularis oculi (Option D): The orbicularis oculi is responsible for eye closure and is innervated by the facial nerve (CN VII).

Learning Objective:

Neurogenic ptosis

  • Third Cranial (Oculomotor) Nerve Palsy: The third nerve can be damaged by trauma, ischemia, infection, tumor, or compression, causing ptosis and diplopia.Oculomotor nerve palsy causes ptosis as it supplies the levator palpebrae superioris muscle.
  • The ptotic eyelid can be elevated with a frontalis sling or levator aponeurosis advancement.
  • Horner's Syndrome: Involves a lesion in the sympathetic pathway, affecting the Müller’s muscle, leading to mild ptosis accompanied by miosis (pupil constriction) and anhidrosis (loss of sweating).
  • Ophthalmoplegic migraine
  • Multiple Sclerosis

Reference:

  1. Horner Syndrome - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf
  2. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK441907/

questions.text: During the Worth 4 Dot Test, a patient sees only three green dots. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
If the patient only sees three green dots, it suggests suppression of the right eye, as the red lens over the right eye would normally allow them to see the red dot. The fact that only green dots are seen indicates that the right eye is not contributing to vision.

WORTH'S FOUR DOT TEST

The patient wears goggles with red lens in front of the right eye and green lens in front of the left eye, and views a box with 4 lights - one red, two green and one white.

Results are interpreted as below:

  • Normal binocular single vision: Patient sees all the four lights in the absence of manifest squint (image A).
  • Abnormal retinal correspondence: Patient sees all four lights even in the presence of a manifest squint.
  • Left eye suppression (Option B): Patient sees only two red lights (image B).
  • Right eye suppression (Option A): Patient sees only three green lights (image C).
  • Alternating suppression: Patient sees three green lights and two red lights, alternately.
  • Diplopia (Option C and D): Patient sees 5 lights (2 red and 3 green) (image D & E).
    • Crossed diplopia (exotropia) → Red dots seen on the left
    • Uncrossed diplopia (esotropia) → Red dots seen on the right

questions.text: A patient presents to the outpatient department with the following findings. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above image is suggestive of a Limbal dermoid.

Key Features of Limbal Dermoid:

  • Congenital lesion (often present since birth)
  • Located at the limbus (junction of cornea and sclera)
  • Non-progressive
  • May contain hair follicles, sebaceous glands, and connective tissue

Pterygium (Option A): A pterygium is a triangular fibrovascular growth that extends onto the cornea, often due to UV exposure. Unlike limbal dermoid, it is progressive and vascularized.

Pyogenic Granuloma (Option C): Pyogenic granuloma is a vascular, red, pedunculated lesion that occurs after trauma or surgery. Unlike limbal dermoid, it is acquired and highly vascularized.

Pinguecula (Option D): A small, yellowish, raised lesion on the bulbar conjunctiva, usually near the limbus but not encroaching onto the cornea. Unlike limbal dermoid, it is acquired due to UV exposure and seen in elderly.

Reference: https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC5728589/#s3

questions.text: A patient presents with decreased vision three years after surgery and exhibits this condition. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Posterior capsular opacification (PCO) is a common complication after cataract surgery.

  • It occurs when the posterior capsule of the lens becomes opacified, leading to decreased visual acuity and glare, particularly at night.
  • The symptoms of glare and decreased visual acuity, along with the fact that the patient has had cataract surgery within the last year, make PCO the most probable diagnosis.

Pseudo-bullous keratopathy (Option A): This condition is due to endothelial dysfunction, leading to corneal edema and bullae formation. Unlike PCO, it presents earlier and is associated with pain and photophobia rather than progressive vision loss.

Corneal dystrophy (Option B): Corneal dystrophies are bilateral, progressive, and hereditary corneal disorders affecting various corneal layers. They do not occur secondary to cataract surgery.

Posterior subcapsular cataract (Option C): PSC affects the posterior lens but occurs before cataract surgery, whereas PCO develops after cataract surgery.

Reference:

  1. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK574505/
  2. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK557865/
  3. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK539699/

questions.text: A patient presents with sudden diminution of vision, difficulty looking towards the light, and circumcorneal congestion with a hypopyon. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The presence of sudden vision loss, photophobia (difficulty looking at light), circumcorneal congestion, and hypopyon strongly suggests acute anterior uveitis.

  • Anterior uveitis is characterized by the presence of fine, grey keratic precipitates (KPs) on the corneal endothelium, a hazy anterior chamber (aqueous flare), and a constricted pupil.

Anterior Uveitis

Definition: Most common type of uveitis affecting the anterior segment of the eye.

Clinical Features:

  • Pain
  • Redness
  • Photophobia (sensitivity to light)
  • Blepharospasm (involuntary blinking)
  • Serous discharge
  • Blurring and diminished vision

Examination Findings:

  • Keratic Precipitates (KPs):
    • Non-Granulomatous: Fine, grey deposits; composed of lymphocytes
    • Granulomatous: Large, greasy-looking deposits known as "mutton fat KPs"; composed of macrophages
    • Location: Typically found in the lower cornea due to convection currents in aqueous humor; this area is known as Arlt's triangle
  • Aqueous Cells:
    • Indicator of active inflammation
  • Aqueous Flare:
    • Haziness in the anterior chamber due to leakage of proteins from inflamed tissues
  • Muddy Iris:
    • Edema in the iris caused by protein leakage
  • Miosis:
    • Constricted pupil due to toxins released from inflamed tissue
  • Nodules on the Iris:
    • Koeppe's Nodules: At the pupillary border; seen in both granulomatous and non-granulomatous uveitis
    • Busacca Nodules: At the base of the iris; seen in granulomatous uveitis

Complications: (Findings)

  • Posterior Synechiae: Iris adheres to the lens; may lead to festooned-shaped pupil
  • Secclusio Pupil/Ring Synechiae: Adhesion along the entire pupillary border; can lead to Iris Bombe and peripheral anterior synechiae, causing angle closure glaucoma
  • Occlusio Pupil: Covers the whole surface of the lens
  • Cyclitic Membrane
  • Rubeosis Iridis: New vessel formation on the iris

Acute conjunctivitis (Option A): Conjunctivitis typically presents with diffuse conjunctival redness, watery/mucoid discharge, and itching (especially in allergic conjunctivitis).

Acute angle closure glaucoma (Option B): Presents with severe ocular pain, headache, nausea, vomiting, and blurred vision with halos around lights. The eye appears hazy with a fixed, mid-dilated pupil, not a hypopyon. IOP is significantly elevated (>40 mmHg), which is a distinguishing feature.

Episcleritis (Option C): Episcleritis causes localized redness without circumcorneal congestion or hypopyon. It is not associated with vision loss or photophobia.

questions.text: Which of the following is seen in the given image?
questions.solution:
Herbert pits are depressions or pits at the limbus, seen in trachoma. They result from the resolution of limbal follicles in chronic Chlamydia trachomatis infection.

Horner-Trantas spots (Option A): These are white, chalky dots seen at the limbus in vernal keratoconjunctivitis. They represent eosinophilic collections in an allergic response. They do not form pits but rather appear as elevated spots.

Pannus (Option C): Pannus is subepithelial fibrovascular tissue growth over the cornea. Commonly seen in trachoma and contact lens-related hypoxia.

Corneal dystrophy (Option D): Corneal dystrophies are bilateral, inherited, progressive opacities affecting different corneal layers. Examples include Reis-Bücklers dystrophy (Bowman's layer) and Macular corneal dystrophy (stroma).

questions.text: A 2-month-old child is brought to the ophthalmology OPD with the following presentation. What is the ideal management?
questions.solution:
The scenario is suggestive of Bilateral congenital cataracts. Delaying surgery in cases of significant cataract can lead to amblyopia (lazy eye) due to sensory deprivation.

Medical management (Option A):

  • Delaying surgery in cases of significant cataract can lead to amblyopia (lazy eye) due to sensory deprivation.
  • Medical management is only supportive and not the primary treatment.

Surgery after 6 months (Option C): Delaying surgery for 6 months can lead to irreversible visual impairment due to deprivation amblyopia.

Surgery after 2 years (Option D): Waiting until 2 years would result in severe amblyopia, making visual rehabilitation nearly impossible.

questions.text: Identify the defect shown in the image given below.
questions.solution:
Homonymous hemianopia refers to loss of vision in the same visual field (right or left) of both eyes.

  • It occurs due to lesions in the optic tract, lateral geniculate body, optic radiations, or occipital cortex.
  • Common causes include stroke, tumors, and traumatic brain injury affecting the contralateral side of the brain.
  • The visual field defect shown is Right Homonymous Hemianopia, which occurs due to a defect in the Left Occipital lobe.
  • Visual Pathway: Temporal fibers carry impulses from the Nasal field, and Nasal fibres carry the Temporal field.

Binasal hemianopia (Option A): Binasal hemianopia involves loss of vision in the nasal fields of both eyes.It is usually caused by bilateral lateral compression of the optic chiasm, such as in bilateral carotid artery aneurysms.

Bitemporal hemianopia (Option B): Bitemporal hemianopia presents with loss of vision in the temporal fields of both eyes. It occurs due to optic chiasm compression, commonly caused by pituitary adenomas, craniopharyngiomas, or suprasellar masses.

Altitudinal defect (Option D): Altitudinal defects affect either the upper or lower half of the visual field in one or both eyes. They are typically seen in ischemic optic neuropathy (AION, NAION) and retinal vascular occlusions.

Learning Objective:

questions.text: The eye examination of a 20-year-old male shows a golden ring on the cornea. What of the following is the investigation of choice to diagnose the condition?
questions.solution:
The golden ring on the cornea seen in this 20-year-old male is characteristic of Kayser-Fleischer rings, which are typically associated with Wilson's disease. Wilson’s disease is a genetic disorder of copper metabolism that leads to copper accumulation in various tissues, including the liver, brain, and cornea.

Kayser-Fleischer rings are copper deposits that form in the Descemet membrane of the cornea, appearing as a golden or greenish ring on slit-lamp examination.

Wilson's disease

  • Deficiency of ceruloplasmin, leading to abnormal copper deposition in tissues.
  • Symptoms:
    • Liver disease
    • Basal ganglia dysfunction (movement disorders)
    • Psychiatric disturbances
  • Ocular Signs:
    • Kayser-Fleischer ring: Brownish-yellow golden copper deposits in the corneal Descemet membrane, visible on gonioscopy.
    • Sunflower cataract: Anterior capsular cataract in some patients.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Kayser-Fleischer rings detected on gonioscopy.
    • Serum Ceruloplasmin levels
  • Treatment: Penicillamine therapy can reduce copper deposits and improve symptoms.

Alpha-1-antitrypsin (Option A): This is a protein associated with lung and liver diseases (like emphysema and cirrhosis), but it is not related to copper metabolism or Wilson's disease.

Alpha-fetoprotein (Option B): This is a tumor marker, often elevated in certain cancers or during pregnancy, but not associated with Wilson’s disease or corneal findings.

Serum iron (Option C): Elevated iron levels are associated with hemochromatosis or iron overload disorders, not with Wilson’s disease.

Reference: Wilson Disease - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf

questions.text: What dye and filter are used in the image, as shown below?
questions.solution:
Fluorescein sodium

Fluorescein penetrates poorly into the lipid layer of the corneal epithelium, and therefore, it does not stain normal cornea. Although fluorescein is a very effective stain for the diseased cornea, it is more difficult to detect fluorescein staining of the conjunctiva because of the poor scleral contrast. Fluorescein absorbs light in the blue spectrum (490 nm) and emits yellow-green light of a higher wavelength (530 nm), therefore staining can be more readily viewed if a cobalt blue or yellow (blue-free) filter is used. This combination is particularly useful for detecting corneal defects and ulcers.

Cobalt blue filter:

Cobalt blue is a filter that is commonly used in conjunction with fluorescein stain, as it enhances the fluorescence of fluorescein, making it easier to detect corneal defects. It absorbs light in the blue spectrum (around 490 nm) and helps the fluorescein stain emit a bright yellow-green fluorescence when illuminated.

Lissamine green dye

It has a high affinity for staining dead and degenerated cells, including mucous strands. The dye appears to stain areas where there are disrupted intercellular junctions. Use of a green (red-free) filter shows the stained areas to appear black in color. As it is better tolerated than rose bengal, it is the preferred dye for staining the bulbar conjunctiva.

Lissamine green dye green filter (Option A):

  • Lissamine green stains dead or degenerated cells and mucous strands on the conjunctiva, not corneal defects.
  • A green filter is used with lissamine green because it enhances contrast, making stained areas appear black. It's not effective for fluorescein.

Lissamine green dye cobalt blue filter (Option B):

  • Lissamine green doesn't fluoresce, so a cobalt blue filter (which works with fluorescein) won't enhance its staining.
  • Cobalt blue is useful for fluorescein fluorescence, not for lissamine green, which requires a green filter.

Fluorescein dye green filter (Option C): Fluorescein works best with a cobalt blue filter for fluorescence, not a green filter. A green filter doesn't enhance fluorescein's fluorescence, making it less effective for detecting corneal defects.

Reference: Ocular surface staining: Current concepts and techniques - PMC (nih.gov)

questions.text: Which of the following refractive errors is associated with the image given below?
questions.solution:
Astigmatism is a refractive error caused by an irregular shape of the cornea or lens, leading to blurred or distorted vision. This results in multiple focal points instead of a single point of focus on the retina.

The image shows irregular, blurry distorted vision or varying focal points and is typically associated with astigmatism, where light entering the eye is refracted unevenly.

Astigmatism

  • A refractive error where the eye's refraction varies across different meridians.
  • As a result, light rays entering the eye do not converge to a single point, instead form focal lines.

Presbyopia (Option A): This is an age-related condition where the eye's ability to focus on near objects decreases, typically around age 40. It causes difficulty in reading or seeing close objects, but it's not associated with distorted vision like astigmatism.

Hypermetropia (Option C) (Farsightedness): In hypermetropia, distant objects are seen clearly, but near objects appear blurry. This is due to a shorter eyeball or less curved cornea, not irregular refraction.

Myopia (Option D) (Nearsightedness): In myopia, nearby objects are seen clearly, but distant objects appear blurry, typically due to a longer eyeball or steeper cornea. It does not cause distorted vision as seen in astigmatism.

Reference: Astigmatism

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for an infant brought in with symptoms of excessive tear production, sensitivity to light, and blepharospasm?
questions.solution:
• True Congenital Glaucoma is characterized by elevated intraocular pressure present during intrauterine life, resulting in ocular enlargement at birth.
  • The presence of Haab's striae, early onset, enlarged corneas, and the classic triad of symptoms (watering, photophobia, and blepharospasm) are all consistent with newborn glaucoma.

Congenital Cataract (Option B): Causes a cloudy lens and poor vision, but doesn't typically cause excessive tearing, light sensitivity, or blepharospasm.

Congenital Dacryocystitis (Option C): Leads to tearing and discharge from a blocked tear duct but doesn't cause light sensitivity or blepharospasm.

Ophthalmia Neonatorum (Option D): Involves eye redness and discharge due to infection at birth, but doesn't cause light sensitivity or spasms.

questions.text: What is the term used to describe the refractive error seen in the ocular examination image of a 60-year-old patient who has complained of reduced distant vision, but no longer requires spectacles for near vision?
questions.solution:
• Myopia=shortsightedness- refractive error where parallel rays of light from distant objects focus in front of the retina when the eye's accommodation is relaxed.
  • Index myopia is a condition that often occurs in older individuals, typically associated with age-related changes in the lens. As we age, the lens of the eye becomes denser and less flexible, which can lead to myopia (nearsightedness) in some cases.
  • The patient has reduced distant vision (a hallmark of myopia) but no longer needs glasses for near vision, which suggests that the lens has become more myopic (thicker or more curved) and is compensating for the near vision loss that typically occurs with presbyopia.
  • Index myopia is usually caused by the increase in refractive index of the lens with age, making it more myopic, particularly for distance vision.

Axial myopia (Option B): Caused by an elongated eyeball. This typically leads to myopia from birth or early in life and doesn't relate to the lens changes seen with aging.

Curvatural myopia (Option C): Caused by a change in the curvature of the cornea, which affects the focusing power of the eye. It's not related to the age-related changes in the lens.

Positional myopia (Option D): Refers to a refractive error caused by the position of the eye or the viewing distance (e.g., looking through different parts of the lens or an unusual gaze position). It's not linked to aging lens changes like index myopia.

Reference: Defining and Classifying Myopia

questions.text: In the image, what are the associated complications observed in a 35-year-old woman who has been diagnosed with rheumatoid arthritis?
questions.solution:
• The diagnosis in this scenario is scleromalacia perforans.
  • It is usually associated with long-standing rheumatoid arthritis and presents with scleral thinning appearing bluish and without signs of inflammation.
  • The underlying cause of scleral thinning is probably ischemia because of vessel damage (type III hypersensitivity).

Scleromalacia Perforans:

Most common in elderly females

Pathophysiology:

  • Associated with long-standing rheumatoid arthritis
  • Melting of the sclera is due to obliteration of arterial supply causing ischemia
  • Vessel damage is mediated by type III hypersensitivity (Option A)

Clinical manifestations:

  • Painless scleral thinning
  • Underlying dark uveal tissue is visible
  • Rarely perforation of the globe

Treatment:

  • No specific therapy
  • Protection of the eye from trauma is very crucial
  • Plenty of topical lubrication
  • Oral NSAIDs
  • Oral steroids
  • Immunomodulatory agents
  • Surgery-scleral patch grafting

Ciliary staphyloma (Option B): This condition involves outpouching of the eye wall near the ciliary body, typically associated with trauma or inflammatory conditions other than rheumatoid arthritis, but it is not a direct complication of RA.

Coloboma (Option C): A coloboma is a congenital defect in the eye, where part of the eye structure (such as the iris or retina) is missing. It is not associated with rheumatoid arthritis.

Malignant melanoma (Option D): This is a type of eye cancer that arises from pigment-producing cells. It is unrelated to rheumatoid arthritis and is not an autoimmune complication.

Reference: Scleromalacia Perforans - EyeWiki

questions.text: What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Pseudoexfoliation syndrome is a condition where an abnormal protein material (pseudoexfoliative material) accumulates in the anterior segment of the eye, especially on the lens capsule, pupillary margin, and the corneal endothelium.
  • This condition can cause the formation of a characteristic white, flaky material around the lens and pupil, which is the hallmark of pseudoexfoliation syndrome. It can lead to increased risk of glaucoma (due to blocked drainage of fluid), cataracts, and other complications.
  • This can lead to phacodonesis (lens wobbling).

Ocular manifestation of Pseudoexfoliation Syndrome (XFS) is characterized by the accumulation of fibrillar, proteinaceous material on various ocular structures, including the lens, iris, and trabecular meshwork.

  • This material can be seen as flaky white deposits on the anterior lens capsule and pupillary margin, often with a distinct clear zone at the center of the lens.
  • It causes secondary open-angle glaucoma, known as pseudoexfoliative glaucoma.
  • The excessive material and pigment clog the trabecular meshwork, increasing intraocular pressure (IOP) and causing damage to the optic nerve, which leads to glaucoma.
  • It also predisposes patients to complications during cataract surgery due to weakened zonules, resulting in lens instability or phacodonesis.

Features of Pseudoexfoliation Syndrome:

  • White flaky deposits on the anterior lens capsule and iris
  • Increased trabecular meshwork pigmentation
  • Elevated IOP, leading to secondary glaucoma
  • Zonular instability and risk of lens dislocation during cataract surgery
  • Mutations in the LOXL1 gene have been strongly associated with PXF, although not all individuals with these mutations develop the disease.
  • More prevalent in elderly patients.

Intraocular foreign body (Option A): This typically causes localized symptoms such as pain, vision changes, or infection. An image of an intraocular foreign body would typically show the object within the eye, which is not characteristic of the findings in pseudoexfoliation syndrome.

Ocular trauma (Option C): Ocular trauma may lead to various findings such as bruising, swelling, or damage to the structures of the eye. It is not characterized by the deposition of material on the lens and anterior segment like in pseudoexfoliation syndrome.

Vossius ring (Option D): This is a pigmented ring on the cornea that results from trauma (usually from a blow to the eye). It is a permanent imprint of the iris pigment on the corneal endothelium and is not related to the findings of white, flaky material seen in pseudoexfoliation syndrome.

questions.text: What will be observed in a patient diagnosed with sympathetic ophthalmitis, and a history of penetrating eye injury?
questions.solution:
The patient is likely experiencing sympathetic ophthalmia, a condition characterized by bilateral granulomatous panuveitis following trauma to one eye. The pathogenesis involves a delayed hypersensitivity reaction (T-cell mediated) to tyrosinase peptide antigens or melanocytes, leading to non-necrotizing granulomatous inflammation in both eyes.

MCP: Multifocal Choroiditis and Panuveitis, BSRC: Birdshot Retinochoroidopathy, ABD: Acute Bilateral Diffuse Uveal Retinitis, VKH: Vogt-Koyanagi-Harada Disease, SFU: Sarcoid-Associated Fuchs Uveitis, TB: Tuberculosis, HSV: Herpes Simplex Virus, VZV: Varicella-Zoster Virus, ARN: Acute Retinal Necrosis

Acute anterior uveitis (Option A): While acute anterior uveitis can occur in sympathetic ophthalmitis, it is not the most characteristic feature. Inflammatory involvement is not limited to just the anterior uvea in sympathetic ophthalmitis, as it typically progresses to involve all layers (hence panuveitis).

Pars planitis (Option B) is a type of intermediate uveitis that primarily affects the pars plana of the eye, but it is not typically associated with sympathetic ophthalmitis. It is a distinct form of uveitis, not related to penetrating trauma or autoimmune responses following injury.

Chronic anterior uveitis (Option D): This is not the typical presentation in sympathetic ophthalmitis. While inflammation can persist, it is more commonly panuveitis (involving both anterior and posterior segments), rather than isolated chronic anterior uveitis.

questions.text: What does this image indicate?
questions.solution:
The image most likely represents keratoconus, characterized by the thinning and cone-shaped bulging of the cornea, leading to visual distortion and irregular astigmatism.

Keratoconus

  • Definition: Progressive, non-inflammatory bilateral ectatic corneal condition affecting the axial part.
  • Pathology: Involves progressive thinning and ectasia of the cornea due to defective synthesis of mucopolysaccharides and collagen.

Clinical Features

  • Symptoms:
    • Defective vision due to progressive myopia and irregular astigmatism, uncorrectable by glasses.
    • Blurred and distorted vision, glare, halos around lights.
    • Light sensitivity and ocular irritation.
    • Visual loss mainly from irregular astigmatism and myopia; secondary loss due to corneal scarring.

Examination Findings

  • Corneal Thinning & Bulging: The Cornea thins near the centre and bulges forward, with the cone apex slightly below the corneal centre.
  • Specific Signs:
    • Distorted Window Reflex: Visual irregularity on corneal reflection.
    • Placido Disc Irregularity: Circles appear irregular.
    • Slit-Lamp Examination:
      • Thinning and ectasia of the central cornea.
      • Opacity at the apex, Fleischer Ring: Brownish ring around the cone, possibly due to haemosiderin in the epithelium.
      • Folds in Descemet's and Bowman's membranes.
      • Vogt Striae: Fine, parallel striae at the apex, best seen with a slit lamp, disappearing with external pressure (vs Haab striae: They are curvilinear breaks in Descemet's membrane, resulting acutely from stretching of the cornea in primary congenital glaucoma).

Oil droplet reflex

  • Retinoscopy: Yawning reflex (scissor reflex) with high oblique/irregular astigmatism.
  • Distant Direct Ophthalmoscopy: Annular dark shadow (oil droplet reflex) separating central and peripheral cornea. A ring of shadow concentric with the margin in the red reflex, resembling an oil droplet.
  • Ophthalmoscope Findings: Irregular Astigmatism: Progressive myopia and irregular astigmatism in later stages, poorly corrected by glasses.
  • Munson's Sign: Localized bulging of the lower lid when looking down (seen in late stages).
  • Keratometer Findings: Malformed, malaligned, and malfocused mires.
  • Corneal Topography: The most sensitive method for early detection (Forme Fruste Keratoconus) shows the shape of the corneal surface.

Vogt's limbal girdle (Option B): This refers to a white or grayish band at the corneal margin, but it is not associated with corneal thinning or bulging, as seen in keratoconus.

Keratoglobus (Option C): This is a rare condition where the cornea is uniformly thin and globular in shape, but it is not associated with the same irregular astigmatism and conical shape as keratoconus.

Corneal dystrophy (Option D): This is a group of inherited disorders that cause abnormal deposits in the cornea, but the presentation is different from keratoconus. It does not typically involve the corneal thinning and cone shape seen in keratoconus.

choices.text: Soft exudate, central retinal vein occlusion

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient with progressive painless loss of vision presents to the ophthalmology OPD. The fundus image of the patient is given below. What could be the probable finding and the cause of it?
questions.solution: Hard exudates are bright yellow, well-defined deposits caused by leakage of fluid rich in lipids and proteins from damaged retinal capillaries. They often form around microaneurysms and, in the macular region, can create a star-shaped pattern (macular fan/ star), which is seen most commonly in diabetic retinopathy (although it can also be seen in Hypertensive retinopathy).

questions.text: What would be the suitable course of action for managing a 15-year-old girl who is non-adherent to wearing spectacles for her myopic astigmatism?
questions.solution:
The most appropriate management for a 15-year-old girl who is not compliant with spectacles for her myopic astigmatism would be spherical equivalent spectacles. Spherical equivalent spectacles provide correction for both myopia (nearsightedness) and astigmatism. They are a non-invasive and reversible option that can effectively improve visual acuity and provide clear vision when worn.

Incorrect Options:

LASIK (Option A) (Laser-Assisted In Situ Keratomileusis): is a surgical procedure that reshapes the cornea to correct refractive errors. It involves creating a corneal flap and using a laser to remove tissue. LASIK is generally not recommended for individuals under the age of 18 as their eyes are still developing. It is also important to consider the patient's non-compliance with spectacles, which raises concerns about their readiness for a surgical procedure.

Femto LASIK (Option C): is a variation of LASIK that uses a femtosecond laser to create the corneal flap. Similar to LASIK, it is a surgical procedure and carries the same considerations and limitations mentioned above.

Implantable collamer lens (Option D): is a type of intraocular lens that is surgically implanted in the eye to correct refractive errors. It involves placing a lens inside the eye, typically in front of the natural lens. Like LASIK, this is a surgical option that may not be suitable for a non-compliant patient, especially considering the patient's age.

questions.text: The person in the image is at the risk of developing?
questions.solution:
Image in the question shows Eyelid coloboma - incomplete closure of the embryonic cleft of eyelid, the patient is at the risk of developing Exposure Keratopathy due to increased exposure of corneal area.

Coloboma:

  • Congenital eye malformations caused by incomplete closure of the embryonic cleft, leading to underdeveloped or missing tissues in the uvea, retina, or extending onto the back of the iris.
  • Types of Coloboma:
    • Typical: Found along the inferior aspect of the eye structures, including the iris, lens, choroid, retina, and optic nerve.
    • Atypical: Occurs in the non-inferior location of the eye, like the upper iris or peripheral retina, which are not along the path of the embryonic fissure.

Neurotrophic and Neuroparalytic Keratopathy:

Neurotrophic Keratopathy:

  • Caused by trigeminal nerve paralysis.
  • Decreased corneal sensation and epithelial desquamation.
  • May follow procedures like Gasserian ganglion removal or blockage, often used in treating trigeminal neuralgia.

Neuroparalytic Keratopathy:

  • This condition occurs due to facial nerve paralysis, leading to lagophthalmos (inability to close the eye) and subsequent corneal exposure.
  • The patient's history does not suggest facial nerve paralysis, making this less likely.

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis for a 7-year-old patient who presented with a white pupillary reflex and underwent enucleation, with histopathological examination revealing the presence of Flexner Wintersteiner rosettes?
questions.solution:
A paediatric patient with leukocoria (white pupillary reflex) and Histiopathology revealing Flexner-Wintersteiner Rosettes is diagnostic of Retinoblastoma. Flexner-Wintersteiner rosette is an example of True rosette and is a highly specific feature of Retinoblastoma.



Incorrect options:

Medulloblastoma (Option B): is a rapidly growing tumor of the brain, is unlikely to present with eye symptoms initially. Histopathology may reveal small round blue cells with Homer-wright pseudorosettes. IHC shows positivity for Synaptophysin+, CD56+, GFAP+.

Rhabdomyosarcoma (Option C): presents with acute painful proptosis. Usually seen in boys in the 1st decade of life. Histopathology may reveal small round blue cells with Homer-wright pseudorosettes. IHC shows positivity for Desmin+.

Astrocytoma (Option D): Histopathology would reveal Fried-egg appearance of tumor cells, Eye manifestations are unlikely to be seen in Astrocytoma.

6th CN palsy (Option C) This affects lateral rectus muscle and inability to abduct the eye towards the side of gaze.

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient diagnosed with primary open-angle glaucoma is started on a topical drug that increases uveoscleral outflow. On follow-up, he reports increased eyelash growth and a change in eye color. Which of the following drugs was most likely prescribed?
questions.solution:
Latanoprost is a PGF2α analogue that increases uveoscleral outflow and can cause hypertrichosis and heterochromia.

Medical management of glaucoma:

1.Medical:

The drugs either decrease the formation of aqueous or increase the drainage to decrease IOP. This is of 2 types:

  1. Topical (6 types)
  2. Systemic (2 types)

Topical:

  • Beta-blockers
    • These decrease the formation of aqueous
    • Eg: Timolol (Option A) , betaxolol
    • C/I in asthma
    • S/E: corneal anesthesia and blepharoconjunctivitis
  • Alpha agonists:
    • They have dual action i.e. they decrease the formation of aqueous and increase the trabecular outflow.
    • Eg: Adrenaline/epinephrine, dipivefrin, brimonidine, and apraclonidine
    • Brimonidine is safe in pregnancy
    • Adrenaline is C/I in aphakic glaucoma
  • Miotics:
    • These increase the trabecular outflow and open the angle blockage
    • Eg: Pilocarpine (Option C)
    • S/E of Pilocarpine: Pseudo myopia, retinal detachment, shallow anterior chamber, iris cysts
  • Topical carbonic anhydrase inhibitors:
    • These decrease the formation of aqueous
    • Eg: dorzolamide and brinzolamide
    • These are C/I in sulpha allergies
  • Newer anti-glaucoma drugs:
    • Netarsudil: this increases the contractile property of the trabecular meshwork, thus increasing the trabecular outflow and it also decreases the aqueous production.
    • It is a Rho-kinase inhibitor
    • S/E: vortex keratopathy
  • PGF2 alpha agonist:
    • It increases the uveoscleral outflow
    • These are also contraindicated in uveitis and asthma
    • For eg- Latanoprost (Option B), bimatoprost, travoprost , tafluprost, and unoprostone isopropyl
    • Latanoprost causes heterochromia iridis
    • Bimatoprost increases both uveoscleral and trabecular outflow
    • Side effects: Hypertrichosis

Systemic:

  • Carbonic anhydrase inhibitor
    • For eg: acetazolamide(Option D), methazolamide
    • S/E: Tingling and numbness, constipation, renal stones, and a bad metallic taste
  • Hyperosmotic agents:
    • These draw aqueous out of the eye
    • For eg: I/V mannitol (C/I in heart disease), glycerol (C/I in diabetes), isosorbide, and urea

questions.text: Identify the test being shown below:
questions.solution:
The image provided corresponds to the Cover uncover test.

Cover-Uncover Test which is used to differentiate between latent squint (heterophoria) and manifest squint (heterotopia).

  • Cover test: Detects Heterotropia (Manifest Squint)
  • Uncover test: Detects Heterophoria (Latent Squint)

Cover-Uncover Test:

  • The cover and uncover tests assess horizontal and vertical strabismus, but not torsional deviations. They also evaluate the ability of each eye to fixate on a target.

Cover Test:

  • Detects Tropias: Measures constant deviations of the visual axis.
  • Procedure:
    • Cover one eye with a paddle, thumb, or occluder.
    • Observe the uncovered eye for movement:
    • Nasal movement: Exotropia
    • Temporal movement: Esotropia
    • Upward movement: Hypotropia
    • Downward movement: Hypertropia
  • For young children, use small toys instead of bright lights.
  • Quantify the deviation with the simultaneous prism and cover test by introducing a prism before one eye until movement stops. Repeat with the prism before the other eye.

Uncover Test:

  • Identifies latent deviations or tropias.
  • Procedure:
    • Cover one eye and then observe the covered eye when the cover is removed.
    • If the eye reverts to fixation, it indicates a phoria or intermittent tropia.
    • If the eye remains deviated, it suggests a tropia with fixation preference for the fellow eye.

Alternate Cover Test: Detects phorias by dissociating the visual axes.

  • Alternate covering each eye to maximize visual axis dissociation.
  • Care must be taken to permit time for each eye to reside behind the cover (the cover must not be "fanned" before the eyes).
  • Use prisms to quantify phorias or tropias. If measurements are unclear, estimate the midpoint between defined movements.

Prism test (Option B): The Prism test is a different diagnostic test used to measure the amount and direction of ocular misalignment. It involves using prismatic lenses to neutralize the misalignment and determine the prism correction required to align the eyes.

Maddox rod test (Option D): The Maddox rod test involves using a cylindrical lens with parallel lines to assess eye alignment and detect muscle imbalances or deviations.

questions.text: Which prescription is appropriate for correcting simple myopic astigmatism?
questions.solution:
Simple Myopic Astigmatism:

  • This condition occurs when one meridian of the eye focuses light on the retina (normal vision), while the perpendicular meridian focuses light in front of the retina (myopia).
  • A cylindrical lens is required to correct the astigmatic meridian. In simple myopic astigmatism, only the affected meridian requires correction.
  • A cylindrical lens like -1.00 DC × 180° is prescribed to address this.

+1.00 DS (Option A): This represents a spherical lens with positive power for correcting hyperopia, which is unrelated to myopia or astigmatism.

-1.00 DS (Option C): This is a spherical lens that corrects myopia uniformly in all meridians, not specific to astigmatism.

-1.00 DS - 1.00 × 180° (Option D): This prescription includes both spherical and cylindrical components, suitable for compound myopic astigmatism (where both meridians are myopic), not simple myopic astigmatism.

Learning Objective:

Steps to identify types of astigmatism:

  • Astigmatism is based on the power of cylindrical lens.
    • +1D Sph = No astigmatism.
  • [+] power means Hypermetropic and [-] means
    • +2D Cyl = Hypermetropic
    • -2D Cyl = Myopic
  • Simple astigmatism is when the power is present only for cylindrical
    • +2D Cyl = Simple Hypermetropic
    • -2D Cyl = Simple Myopic
  • Compound astigmatism is when the same sign power is present for both Spherical and Cylindrical lenses.
    • +1D Sph +2D Cyl = Compound Hypermetropic
    • -1D Sph -2D Cyl = Compound Myopic
  • Mixed astigmatism is when the power of both lenses has opposite signs and the numerical value of the power of cylindrical lens is greater than spherical lens, irrespective of the sign.
    • +1D Sph -2D Cyl = Mixed
    • -1D Sph +2D Cyl = Mixed
  • With the rule and against the rule can be calculated using this simple table.
  • In the case of Spherical lens having greater power than cylindrical lens the concept of simple transposition is applied.
    • Consider -xD Sph & +yD Cyl where x>y,
      • New Sph = Old Sph - Old Cyl
      • New Cyl = Opposite sign of Old Cyl
      • New Axis = Perpendicular to Old Axis
    • -2D Sph & +1D Cyl @90 degrees=?
      • New Sph = -2 +1 = -1D
      • New Cyl = -1D
      • New Axis = 180 degrees
      • -1D Sph -1D Cyl @180 degrees = Compound Myopic astigmatism with the rule

Note: This is based on the power of the cylindrical lens and axis only.


Reference: Astigmatism

questions.text: The yoke muscle of the right lateral rectus in dextroversion is _________________.
questions.solution:
• Yoke muscles are pairs of extraocular muscles, one in each eye, that work together to ensure coordinated eye movements in the same direction.
  • These muscles function according to Hering's Law of Equal Innervation, which ensures that corresponding muscles in both eyes receive equal neural impulses for synchronised movement.
  • In dextroversion (right gaze), the right lateral rectus abducts the right eye, while the left medial rectus adducts the left eye.

The yoke muscle pairs facilitate various eye movements:



  1. Horizontal Gaze (Left or Right):
    • Leftward Gaze (Levoversion):
      • Left Lateral Rectus (abducts the left eye)
      • Right Medial Rectus (adducts the right eye)
    • Rightward Gaze (Dextroversion):
      • Right Lateral Rectus (abducts the right eye)
      • Left Medial Rectus (adducts the left eye)
  2. Vertical Gaze (Up or Down):
    • Upward Gaze (Elevation):
      • Right and Left Superior Rectus (elevate the eyes) (Option D ruled out)
      • Right and Left Inferior Oblique (assist in elevation)
    • Downward Gaze (Depression):
      • Right and Left Inferior Rectus (depress the eyes) (Option C ruled out)
      • Right and Left Superior Oblique (assist in depression) (Option A ruled out)
  3. Inward Gaze (Convergence):
    • Both Medial Rectus muscles contract to bring the eyes inward (toward the nose) during near-vision tasks, such as reading.

Learning Objective:

questions.text: What is the most common site of an orbital blowout fracture?
questions.solution:
• An orbital blowout fracture occurs when a blunt trauma to the orbit causes a fracture of one of its walls while sparing the orbital rim.
  • The orbital floor and medial wall are the weakest points of the orbital cavity, making them more prone to fractures.
  • Most Common Site: Orbital Floor

Bones of Orbit

Medial Wall (Thinnest):

  • Frontal process of maxilla (anterior-most)
  • Lacrimal bone
  • Orbital plate of ethmoid (posterior to lacrimal process)
  • Body of sphenoid (posterior-most)

Lateral Wall (Strongest):

  • Orbital surface of zygomatic bone (anterior part)
  • Orbital surface of greater wing of sphenoid (posterior part)

Floor:

  • Orbital surface of body of maxilla (medial part)
  • Orbital surface of zygomatic bone (anterolateral part)
  • Orbital process of the palatine bone (posteromedial part)

Roof:

  • Orbital plate of the frontal bone (anterior part)
  • Lesser wing of the sphenoid (posterior part)

Learning Objective:

Key features:

  • Weakest Wall of the Orbit:
    • Medial wall is the thinnest due to the cribriform plate of ethmoid.
  • Blowout Fracture: Fracture of floor of the orbit due to blunt trauma.
  • Weakest Part of the Floor: Posteromedial Part of the orbit.

Reference:

  1. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK534825/

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect about Retinitis Pigmentosa?
questions.solution:
Night Blindness is the characteristic and earliest feature of retinitis pigmentosa and may present several years before the visible changes in the retina appear.

Retinitis Pigmentosa:

  • Retinitis pigmentosa is a dystrophy of rods and cones, initially, rods are affected.(Option B ruled out)
  • Most common hereditary fundus dystrophy.
  • It can be sporadic (40-50%) or hereditary.
  • If hereditary, autosomal dominant is the most common mode of inheritance followed by autosomal recessive (AR). X-linked recessive inheritance is the least severe form.

Clinical features:

Symptoms:

  • Nyctalopia (night blindness) (Option D)
  • Peripheral visual field loss
  • Mid-peripheral superior scotoma leads to ring/ doughnut scotoma resulting in tubular/ tunnel vision. Central vision is affected in later stages (Option C ruled out)

Signs:

  • Triad of a pale waxy disc due to consecutive optic atrophy, attenuation of arteries, and pigmentation disturbance in the form of bony spicules.
  • Tapetal reflex: shinning reflex at macula - seen in female carriers of XLR inheritance.

Atypical Retinitis Pigmentosa

  • Atypical retinitis pigmentosa includes heterogeneous disorders that share clinical features with typical pigmentary retinal dystrophy.
  • Conditions included are:
    • RP sine pigmento - absence or paucity of pigment accumulation
    • Retinitis punctata albescens - scattered whitish-yellow spots with arteriolar attenuation, usually sparing the macula.
    • Sectoral RP - only inferior quadrants are involved.

Investigation of Retinitis Pigmentosa

  • Electroretinography (ERG) is the investigation of choice - reduced scotopic rod in early disease and reduced photopic with progression.
  • EOG- subnormal- absence of light rise.
  • Perimetry: initially small mid-peripheral scotomas which gradually merge and may progress, leaving only a small island of residual central vision.
  • Electroretinography (ERG): There's a decreased amplitude of both "a" and "b" waves.(Option A ruled out)
  • OCT- to identify cystoid macular edema (CME).
  • Dark adaptometry: Dark adaptation time is prolonged.
  • Decreased Arden ratio may be present.

questions.text: A patient with rheumatoid arthritis who is noncompliant with treatment presents with complaints of superior field loss of vision for the past week. What is the most likely cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
• Branched retinal vein occlusion occurs as quadrantic occlusion due to occlusion at the level of AV crossing.
  • It is mostly seen in the superotemporal retinal as AV crossings are more in this area, so the chances of blockage are higher.
  • In this case, the patient is presenting with superior field loss of vision due to blockage in the inferior branch retinal vein.

Branch Retinal Vein Occlusion (BRVO)

BRVO occurs when a single branch of the central retinal vein is occluded, causing retinal edema and hemorrhages localized to the area supplied by the blocked vein.

  • Visual Defects:
    • Visual loss is partial, superior or inferior field loss, depending on the location of the occlusion.
    • Prognosis for central vision is better unless the macula is involved, often seen in superior temporal vein occlusion.
  • Complications:
    • Neovascularization and secondary glaucoma are rare but can occur in cases of widespread capillary occlusion.
  • Diagnostic Features:
    • Fluorescein Angiography: Shows areas of hypofluorescence, incomplete perifoveal arcades, and capillary closure in poorly perfused areas.
    • Widespread capillary occlusion is associated with cotton-wool spots, delayed arteriovenous transit time, vessel leakage, and retinal edema.
  • Treatment:
    • No definitive treatment is effective once complete venous blockage occurs.
    • Panphotocoagulation or Cryotherapy: Used to prevent complications like neovascular glaucoma and rubeosis iridis in cases of widespread capillary occlusion.
    • Photocoagulation: Should only be performed after intraretinal blood absorption to address areas of poor perfusion, reducing edema and neovascularization risk.
    • Anti-VEGF Therapy: Intravitreal injections are now standard for improving visual recovery and preventing late complications.

Branched retinal artery occlusion (Option A) a cherry red spot in the retina is noticed due to the surrounding edema.

Central retinal artery occlusion (Option B) obstruction occurs at the level of the lamina cribrosa, causing sudden painless loss of vision within seconds.

Central retinal vein occlusion (Option D) there is a mild blurring of vision, which improves over the day.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about macular opacity?
questions.solution:
Macular opacity refers to an opacity in the lens or cornea that affects the passage of light and vision. The extent to which the iris and pupil are visible depends on the density and location of the opacity.

  • In macular opacity, the central part of the lens is affected, which significantly impairs central vision and causes a "shadowing" effect in the visual axis.
  • As a result, only the pupillary margin is visible, while details of the iris may be obscured due to the opacity.

Iris and pupil are visible (Option A): If both the iris and pupil were completely visible, it would suggest the absence of significant central opacity, which contradicts the question.

Iris details are visible (Option C): If iris details were visible, it would imply minimal or no opacity, which is incorrect for macular opacity.

Iris and pupillary margin are not visible (Option B): This would be true for total opacity (e.g., mature cataract or dense corneal opacity), but macular opacity allows limited peripheral visualization.

Learning Objective:

Corneal Opacities:

Nebular opacity

  • A faint opacity is noted covering the central cornea
  • Although faint, a nebular opacity can severely impact vision, particularly if it covers the pupillary area.
  • The irregular refraction caused by the nebula distorts the image more than a denser opacity like leucoma, leading to greater visual discomfort and blurring.

Macular corneal opacity: This semi-dense opacity affects the cornea less than a nebula regarding irregular refraction, but it still causes significant visual impairment.


Leucomatous corneal opacity : While this dense white opacity blocks light more completely, it causes less irregular refraction than a nebula. If it doesn't cover the entire pupillary area, it may not affect vision as much as a nebula.


Adherent leucoma: This is a dense opacity associated with iris incarceration and is typically more significant in light blockage, but its effect on vision varies depending on the extent of iris involvement.


Management of corneal opacity:

  • Optical Iridectomy: This procedure can be used for central macular or leucomatous opacities when vision improves with pupil dilation.
  • Phototherapeutic Keratectomy (PTK): PTK uses an excimer laser, and is effective for treating superficial corneal opacities, such as
  • Keratoplasty
  • Cosmetic-Coloured Contact Lenses: These lenses offer a cosmetic solution for unsightly scars in the eyes without visual potential.
  • Corneal Tattooing: It is mainly reserved for firm scars in eyes with no useful vision.

questions.text: Identify the marked structure:
questions.solution:
The Canal of Petit (also known as Spatia Zonularia) is a sacculated canal that encircles the equator of the lens, formed by the zonular fibers (the zonule of Zinn) that anchor the lens to the ciliary body. This canal is located behind the suspensory ligament of the lens and contains aqueous humor in the interstices between the zonules. It is an important anatomical feature in the structure of the eye.

Zonular Spaces (Spatia Zonularia):

  • Zonular fibers, also known as the zonule of Zinn, anchor the lens to the ciliary body and the ciliary part of the retina. These fibers are separated by spaces filled with aqueous humor, referred to as zonular spaces.
  • Anatomy: The zonules form a fibrous ring around the equator of the lens, connecting it to the ciliary body. The spaces between the zonules form a sacculated canal known as Hannover's Canal or Petit's Canal or Petit's spaces (spatia zonularia), which encircles the lens' equator.
  • Function: These spaces are involved in the structure and function of the ciliary zonule, providing mechanical support for the lens and contributing to accommodation. The canal can be inflated using a fine blowpipe inserted under the suspensory ligament.

Canal of Hannover (Option B): Another term related to zonular anatomy, but it refers to a slightly different structure and is often used interchangeably with the Canal of Petit in some contexts. However, in this case, the correct answer is Canal of Petit.

Hyaloid Canal (Option C): This is a different structure in the eye, located within the vitreous body, and is the remnant of the fetal hyaloid artery. It is not related to the zonules or lens attachment.

Pars Plana (Option D): A region of the retina, part of the ciliary body, involved in ocular surgeries (like vitrectomy) but not related to the canal structures surrounding the lens.

Reference:

Zonular spaces - e-Anatomy - IMAIOS

questions.text:
What is the accurate order of staining in patients with dry eyes?
1. Fluorescein stain
2. Lissamine green
3. Rose Bengal stain
questions.solution:
In the management of dry eye syndrome, different stains are used to assess the health of the ocular surface. The typical order of staining is as follows:

  1. Fluorescein Stain:
    • First step: Fluorescein is typically used first to highlight epithelial defects and tear film stability. It is a bright yellow-green dye that fluoresces under cobalt blue light, marking areas of corneal epithelial damage. It can also help assess the tear break-up time (TBUT).
  2. Lissamine Green:
    • Second step: Lissamine green is a vital dye that stains dead or degenerated cells in the conjunctiva and cornea, often used to evaluate the conjunctival surface in dry eyes. It is less irritating than Rose Bengal, making it ideal for dry eye patients, and it stains areas with poor tear film or disrupted epithelial integrity.
  3. Rose Bengal Stain:
    • Third step: Rose Bengal stains damaged epithelial cells in the conjunctiva and cornea, particularly in cases of severe dryness. It can be more irritating to the eye than the other two stains, so it is typically used last in the staining sequence. It is helpful in identifying severe damage, such as conjunctival filaments or corneal ulcers.

Options A, C, & D are incorrect.

Reference:

  1. Diagnosis of dry eye disease and emerging technologies - PMC
  2. Schirmer Test - an overview | ScienceDirect Topics
  3. Evaluation of Phenol Red Thread test versus Schirmer test in dry eyes: A comparative study - PMC

questions.text: In the provided image, which nerve is subjected to blockage?
questions.solution:
The given image represents the nasociliary nerve block.

The nasociliary nerve is typically targeted for blockage in procedures involving the ophthalmic region, especially in the context of blocking sensations to the eye and adjacent structures.

The nasociliary nerve, as a branch of the ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve (V1), plays a central role in sensory innervation to the eye, cornea, and adjacent regions, which is why it is the primary target in many ophthalmic nerve blocks.

Nasociliary nerve block

  • The nasociliary nerve is a branch of the ophthalmic division (V1) of the trigeminal nerve (CN V).
  • It provides sensory innervation to structures such as the cornea, conjunctiva, sclera, ciliary body, and parts of the nose.
  • Indications for Block:
    • Ocular surgery (e.g., cataract surgery, corneal procedures).
    • Pain management in conditions like corneal ulcers, ocular trauma, or sinusitis.
    • Techniques:
  • Injection Site: The needle is typically inserted near the medial canthus of the eye, in the area where the nasociliary nerve is located close to the lacrimal sac.
  • Injection Approach: The needle is advanced medially, just lateral to the nasal bone, and injected near the nerve's location.
  • Anatomy: The nasociliary nerve travels within the orbit, giving off branches like the long ciliary nerves, posterior ethmoidal, and anterior ethmoidal nerves.
  • Procedure:
    • Patient Positioning: The patient is usually seated or supine with the eye to be blocked exposed.
    • Needle Insertion: A 25-30 gauge needle is used, inserted near the medial canthus, directed medially and slightly superiorly.
    • Local Anesthetic: A small amount (0.5-1 mL) of local anesthetic is injected near the nasociliary nerve for effective blockage.
  • Benefits:
    • Provides anesthesia to the cornea, conjunctiva, and other associated structures in the orbit.
    • Helps in treating ocular pain or managing intraocular procedures with minimal discomfort.
  • Complications:
    • Hematoma
    • Inadvertent block of other branches, leading to side effects like lid drooping or ptosis.

Anterior ethmoidal nerve (Option A) is a branch of the nasociliary nerve. It primarily provides sensation to the anterior part of the nasal cavity and the skin of the nose. Although it can be blocked in certain procedures, it is not the primary nerve blocked in typical ophthalmic procedures.

Supratrochlear nerve (Option C) is responsible for sensation in the forehead and scalp, specifically in the area above the eye. This nerve is not typically involved in the same procedures as the nasociliary nerve, which innervates the eye and surrounding structures.

Long ciliary nerves (Option D) are branches of the nasociliary nerve and are responsible for innervating the cornea, iris, and the ciliary body. They may be involved in certain procedures but are not usually blocked on their own without affecting the nasociliary nerve.

Reference: Consensus recommendations for anaesthetic peripheral nerve block - ScienceDirect

questions.text: Which of the following is not characteristic of pterygium?
questions.solution:
• Pterygium is a fibrovascular growth that arises from the conjunctiva and extends onto the cornea, typically affecting the nasal side of the eye. (Option B ruled out)
  • The parts of a pterygium include: (Option C ruled out)
    • Head: The part that grows onto the cornea.
    • Neck: The transition zone between the conjunctiva and the cornea.
    • Body: The part on the conjunctiva.
  • Pterygium has progressive and regressive types, meaning it can either grow over time (progressive) or shrink back (regressive) in some cases. (Option D ruled out)
  • The rate of recurrence after surgical removal of pterygium is typically around 30-40%, not 95%. This high rate of recurrence is more common in certain settings (e.g., incomplete excision or lack of adjunctive treatments like conjunctival autografting or mitomycin C). A 95% recurrence rate is uncharacteristically high and is not the typical outcome. (Option A)

questions.text: Which of the following does not characterize complicated cataracts?

It is characterized by vertical brownish streaks on the cornea due to pigment being deposited by the inflamed iris. It does not describe a characteristic of cataracts.

questions.text: Identify the surgical step shown in the image given below:
questions.solution:
The surgical procedure where tryphan blue dye is being injected in the image is Continuous curvilinear Capsulorrhexis. It refers to the creation of a circular tear in the anterior capsule of the lens.

Surgical Steps of Conventional ECCE:

  1. Eye Stabilization: Superior rectus suture for downward gaze(known as bridle suture)
  2. Conjunctival Flap Creation: A fornix-based flap will be used to expose the limbus.
  3. Limbal Incision: Partial-thickness groove across the limbus.
  4. Anterior Chamber Access: Entry with a razor blade knife or keratome.
  5. Viscoelastic Injection: Maintains chamber depth and protects the cornea.
  6. Anterior Capsulotomy/ Capsulorrhexis: Methods include can-opener, linear capsulotomy, envelope, or CCC. Tryphan blue dye is usually injected. (Option B)
  7. Capsule Removal: Using forceps remove the cut capsule.
  8. Corneoscleral Section Completion: Extending the incision.
  9. Hydrodissection: Separates the lens from the capsule. (Option A)
  10. Nucleus Removal: Methods include pressure/counter pressure or irrigating wire vectis.
  11. Lens Cortex Aspiration: Using a two-way cannula. (I/A) (Option D)
  12. IOL Implantation: Posterior chamber IOL into the capsular bag. (Option C)
  13. Incision Closure: With sutures.
  14. Viscoelastic Removal: Followed by refilling the anterior chamber with irrigating fluid.
  15. Conjunctival Flap Repositioning: Secured in place.
  16. Subconjunctival Injections: Dexamethasone and gentamicin.
  17. Eye Patching: Final step.

questions.text: Which of the following is the site of lesion in internuclear ophthalmoplegia (INO)?
questions.solution:
Internuclear ophthalmoplegia (INO) results from a lesion in the MLF, a heavily myelinated fiber tract that coordinates conjugate eye movements by linking the abducens nucleus (CN VI) of one side to the oculomotor nucleus (CN III) of the opposite side.


  • Internuclear Ophthalmoplegia (INO)
    • Injury to the MLF between the abducens nucleus and the contralateral oculomotor nerve's medial rectus subnucleus.
    • Impaired adduction of the ipsilateral eye, with slow or absent adduction during lateral gaze.
    • The abducting eye overshoots the target (dysmetria), resulting in disconjugate nystagmus.
    • Convergence is typically preserved.
  • Bilateral INO Features
    • Abduction saccades may be slow due to impaired inhibition of medial rectus resting tone.
    • Associated with upward beating and torsional nystagmus.
  • Associated Clinical Features
    • Skew deviation.
    • Defective vertical smooth pursuit.
    • Impairment of the vertical VOR and difficulty suppressing it.
  • Causes of INO
    • Vascular, demyelinating, or metastatic brainstem lesions.
    • Must be differentiated from pseudo-INO caused by myasthenia gravis, paraneoplastic strabismus, or long-standing exotropia.

6th nerve nucleus (Option B): A lesion in the abducens (6th nerve) nucleus would cause a horizontal gaze palsy, not INO. The MLF lesion in INO spares the abducens nucleus, meaning the lateral rectus muscle still functions normally.

Pontine paramedian reticular formation (PPRF) (Option C): The PPRF is responsible for generating horizontal saccadic eye movements. A lesion here would cause horizontal gaze palsy rather than INO.

A & C (Option D): Since INO is specifically due to MLF damage, PPRF involvement is not necessary.
